text: An interesting thing about prepositions is that they have a habit of changing between languages.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: To give you an example, in English we say, I fall in love with.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: In Spanish, you say, I enamour myself of.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: I fall in love of you.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Now, again, this is something that we look at with interest rather than looking at it as an obstacle for the insight that it might give us about how we perceive and express the world through our own language.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Now, the fact that we use with is not necessarily casual.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Casual in the sense of meaningless.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: The fact that we use with is not necessarily without its weight, without its meaning.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: If I say, I fall in love with you, that preposition with necessarily involves you in my process of falling in love.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Now, this of is much more detached in feeling than with.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So there is a school of thought which explores how these elements of language might have a real tangible effect on the way we interact with the world and with certain concepts and the way we express them and how that feeds back into the way we perceive and view the world.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And I think this is a very nice example between falling in love with and falling in love of.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So this is something to think about and just take interest in whenever you find that in Spanish the verb uses a different preposition than the one it does in English, rather than just seeing it as a hurdle to correctness that you need to memorize.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Maybe have a little look at how it might actually be affecting somehow or other the way you perceive the world.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: This also helps the memory on a practical level.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: You are much more capable of internalizing and remembering this difference if rather than just mindlessly memorizing that you're using de instead of con.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Here we are looking with a more analytical eye, with a curious eye, to understand what effect this might possibly have on us.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And in this way we're just going to learn the differences much easier.
speaker: Speaker 1

speaker: Speaker 1

text: You still have a verb there ending ar, enamorar, and then the se is just hooked on.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So let's start with I fall in love.

text: Now if you want to say I fall in love with you, we're probably going to speak informally.

text: In Spanish we're not going to say with you, we're going to say of you.

text: I fall in love with him.

text: Good, you can come actually after the ando or before estoy.

text: Another verb that uses a different preposition in Spanish and English is the verb to think.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: To think, we said it was related to the word pensiv, which means thoughtful.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Now you don't say I think about you in Spanish, you say I'm thinking or I think in or on you.

speaker: Speaker 1

text: I think we looked at it very briefly.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So we say I think in you or on you.

text: It's probably in actually because Arabic says it in this way and of course when languages come into contact like the 800 years of contact that Spanish and Arabic had, they share a lot more than vocabulary, they also share structures.

text: So we're probably saying I'm thinking in you to say I think about you.
